author: By David Peisner
title: A New Generation Pushes Nashville to Address Racism in Its Ranks
description: A small contingent of country artists and industry players have been speaking up in a business that likes to shut down dissent.
content: Less than 30 minutes after TMZ posted a video of the country star Morgan Wallen using a racial slur on Feb. 2, Mickey Guyton, the only Black female country singer signed to a major label, tweeted her reaction: “The hate runs deep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Say It With Carbonara
description: You could say “I love you” with chocolate, but isn’t a bacony, eggy, cheesy pasta so much better?
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, though really my thoughts are with dessert today, chocolate desserts in particular. Sunday is Valentine’s Day, and while I have zero plans to cook an elaborate dinner, and might even order takeout, I will grab this moment to make something obscenely chocolaty. The current contenders: chocolate lava cake, double chocolate cookies, bittersweet chocolate soufflé or maybe even a chocolate caramel tart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: A Tense Lunar New Year for the Bay Area After Attacks on Asian-Americans
description: The attacks have renewed fears over a wave of anti-Asian violence and harassment that was spurred earlier in the pandemic.
content: The videos are graphic and shocking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Nikki Haley Slams Trump’s Election Claims: ‘We Shouldn’t Have Followed Him’
description: Although the former United Nations ambassador calibrated her comments, her sharp criticism represented a departure from other Republicans who are believed to be considering running for president in 2024.
content: Nikki R. Haley, a former United Nations ambassador under President Donald J. Trump who left the administration without the drama or ill will that marred most of its high-level departures, sharply criticized her former boss in an interview published on Friday, saying that she was “disgusted” by his conduct on Jan. 6, the day of the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Maggie Haberman, Mark Mazzetti and Annie Karni
title: Donald Trump’s bout with Covid-19 was more serious than acknowledged at the time.
description: President Donald J. Trump was sicker with Covid-19 in October than publicly acknowledged at the time, with extremely depressed blood oxygen levels at one point and a lung problem associated with pneumonia caused by the coronavirus, according to four people familiar with his condition.
content: President Donald J. Trump was sicker with Covid-19 in October than publicly acknowledged at the time, with extremely depressed blood oxygen levels at one point and a lung problem associated with pneumonia caused by the coronavirus, according to four people familiar with his condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Grand Jury Votes Not to Indict Buffalo Police Officers Accused of Shoving Protester
description: The officers had been charged with assault after a widely shared video showed them pushing Martin Gugino, a 75-year-old protester who landed hard on the sidewalk.
content: A grand jury has declined to indict two Buffalo police officers who were facing felony assault charges for shoving a 75-year-old protester who landed hard on the ground and seriously injured his head, prosecutors said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: The First Book That Turned Me On
description: For Valentine’s Day, some titles that first inspired a certain passion in their readers, beyond the literary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Refugees Flee Central African Republic, a Crisis the World Neglects
description: An unlikely alliance of rebels is laying siege to the capital, displacing about 200,000 people, after a disrupted election. Here is an explanation of a humanitarian crisis that gets scant attention.
content: In the shadow of six surrounding neighbors burdened with their own problems sits the Central African Republic, a landlocked country that gets relatively little attention but that has been plagued by instability and conflict upending the lives of its citizens for many years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Love Language of Butter
description: What’s the highest form of love? For Yotam Ottolenghi, it’s made from simple ingredients: tinned anchovies and beans, and lots of brown butter.
content: LONDON — Around Valentine’s Day, I raise my glass particularly high to any couple who managed to save up any top chat for a romantic dinner for two. What on earth is there to talk about when you haven’t been anywhere or done anything for a very long time? In the absence of such discussion, may I present three ways to remind someone why they love you: the general concept of cupboard love; the very specific qualities of butter; and the particularly special advantages of brown butter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Harrison Smith
title: Show and Tell: 4 Picture Books About Friendship
description: Overcoming shyness and isolation via notes, pictures and a pine cone.
content: BEST FRIEND IN THE WHOLE WORLDBy Sandra Salsbury
source.name: The New York Times

title: Impeachment, Oil, Bruce Springsteen: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Concepción de León
title: Three Men Are Accused in Scheme to Sell Covid-19 Vaccines
description: Prosecutors said the men created a fake duplicate of the Moderna website to fraudulently sell doses of the vaccine, which they never had.
content: Three Baltimore men have been accused by federal prosecutors of putting up a fake website to sell Covid-19 vaccines for $30 a dose, prosecutors say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: F.D.A. Agrees Moderna Can Increase Vaccine Supply in Each Vial
description: Federal regulators are in favor of a simple, potentially quick fix to bolster coronavirus vaccine supplies: more doses per bottle.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration has informed the drugmaker Moderna that it can put up to 40 percent more coronavirus vaccine into each of its vials, a simple and potentially rapid way to bolster strained supplies, according to people familiar with the company’s operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Bubba Wallace Needed NASCAR Help. Michael Jordan Took It Personally.
description: Denny Hamlin, who won the Daytona 500 the past two years, asked Jordan to form a team with him, 23XI Racing. They are rallying behind Wallace, the only Black full-time driver at NASCAR’s top level.
content: Michael Jordan started receiving text messages from friends who had never before shown interest in NASCAR after Darrell Wallace Jr. made an impression this week in the run-up to Sunday’s Daytona 500. Wallace, who is known as Bubba, is making his debut with 23XI Racing, the team owned by Jordan and the driver Denny Hamlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Woven, Versatile Bags for Spring
description: Basket-inspired accessories made for carrying everything from lipstick to lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Massachusetts’ vaccine buddy system sets off ‘old rush.’
description: This week, Massachusetts launched a first-in-the-nation experiment, offering vaccinations to younger people who accompany people who are 75 and older to mass vaccination sites.
content: This week, Massachusetts launched a first-in-the-nation experiment, offering vaccinations to younger people who accompany people who are 75 and older to mass vaccination sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak
title: With the Economy on the Ropes, Hungary Goes All In on Mass Vaccination
description: Hungary became the first European Union country to administer Russia’s Sputnik vaccine, and will soon start with one from China — posing a challenge to the bloc’s joint vaccination strategy.
content: Hungary on Friday began injecting citizens with Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine, becoming the first country in the European Union to administer a coronavirus inoculation that has yet to be tested and approved by the bloc’s regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Pizza Was the Restaurant Hero of 2020
description: Its ease and affordability made it a pandemic staple for many families and a rare bright spot in an industry that has been decimated.
content: A few times a week, Elizabeth Reninger ambles to a pizza restaurant near her job for lunch. She orders the same thing every time: a cheese slice and fries for $6. For a little adventure, she sprinkles on some Parmesan and red pepper flakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Chang
title: Connecting My Children to Their Heritage in Mandarin
description: Although my parents’ English is serviceable, it is only in Mandarin that they’re at ease, that they can inhabit their own skins.
content: On Sunday afternoons, my grandfather would sit by my elbow while I gripped his prized calligraphy brush, tracing inky lines on tissue-thin paper. “Many Chinese consider calligraphy a high form of art,” my grandfather reminded me whenever my attention flagged or arm drooped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Impeachment, Schools Reopening, Valentine’s Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: Officers’ Injuries, Including Concussions, Show Scope of Violence at Capitol Riot
description: The impeachment trial of former President Donald J. Trump has heightened attention on the rioters’ attacks on officers, some of which resulted in serious damage.
content: One officer lost the tip of his right index finger. Others were smashed in the head with baseball bats, flag poles and pipes. Another lost consciousness after rioters used a metal barrier to push her into stairs as they tried to reach the Capitol steps during the assault on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Chappelle’s Show’ Returns to Netflix After Dave Chappelle Gets Paid
description: The comedian had asked fans to boycott his sketch show from the mid-2000s because of what he described as a “raw deal” from Comedy Central.
content: Last fall, Dave Chappelle asked his fans to boycott his old Comedy Central sketch show, “Chappelle’s Show,” in order to put pressure on ViacomCBS to rectify his grievances over a contract he signed as a young comedian, and prominent streaming services agreed to pull the show at his request. The tactic seems to have worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Justin Timberlake Apologizes to Britney Spears and Janet Jackson
description: “I understand that I fell short,” he said on Instagram, adding that he “benefited from a system that condones misogyny and racism.”
content: The singer and actor Justin Timberlake apologized to Britney Spears and Janet Jackson on Friday in a vague but earnest Instagram post, a week after a New York Times documentary on Spears set off a wave of criticism of Timberlake for how he treated the pop star after their breakup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman, Stephen Castle and Eshe Nelson
title: 53 Tons of Rotting Pork and Other Brexit Nightmares
description: With Britain out of the European Union, companies that trade with the continent are contending with expensive disruptions to their businesses and a plunge in exports.
content: LONDON — As the new year made Brexit a reality, Tony Hale encountered the pitfalls of Europe’s redrawn geography. Specifically, he confronted the need to extricate 53 tons of rotting pork products from administrative purgatory at a port in the Netherlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Spring Break’s New Look: Older and Socially Distant
description: Beach parties in Florida, Texas and Mexico made headlines a year ago for ignoring virus safety advice. Here’s how the travel ritual will look different in 2021.
content: Last year, Covid-19 crashed the spring break party, but not before mass gatherings on the beaches of Florida, Texas and Mexico flouted travel warnings and social-distancing advice. Ski areas had to shut down during one of the busiest periods of the season. Student trips for enrichment and sport were suddenly canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan A. Knee
title: The Business of Basketball
description: Two new books chronicle the early stages of the evolution of the N.B.A. into the cultural and economic force it is today.
content: This originally appeared as part of the DealBook newsletter on Dec. 24, 2020. To sign up, click here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Sorry, Britney’: Media Is Criticized for Past Coverage, and Some Own Up
description: Conversations about the relentless focus on the pop star’s mental health, mothering and sexuality have begun anew following The New York Times documentary “Framing Britney Spears.”
content: “Help Me,” the cover of Us Weekly blared in all caps, below a photo of Britney Spears with her hair partly buzzed off. People Magazine promised to take readers “Inside Britney’s Breakdown,” teasing details of “wild partying, sobbing in public, shaving her head.” OK! Weekly tempted potential buyers with a firsthand account of an “emotional cry for help.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: A Fight to Save a Corporate Campus Intertwined With Nature
description: The Weyerhaeuser site near Seattle, praised for its balance of building and landscape, is at the center of a battle between conservationists and a developer.
content: Protests often erupt over proposals to demolish or even alter historic buildings. Threats to landscaping usually get far less attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Any Advice on What to Wear for Your First Job?
description: Vanessa Friedman, fashion director of The New York Times, takes reader questions.
content: Way back at the start of the pandemic, Reese Witherspoon’s fashion label, Draper James, had the well-intentioned idea to do a free-dress giveaway in honor of the nation’s teachers, who were suddenly being appreciated in a whole new way. Unfortunately, the response was so enormous that the site crashed almost immediately, the company didn’t have nearly enough supply to meet the demand, and a lot of teachers, instead of being happy, felt really betrayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Danny Hakim
title: Former Lincoln Project Workers Ask to Be Released From Nondisclosure Agreements
description: Leaders of the anti-Trump group came under fire from former workers who want to talk about John Weaver, a co-founder who harassed young men.
content: Leaders of the Lincoln Project, the anti-Trump media venture, came under fire on Thursday night from six former workers demanding to be released from nondisclosure agreements in order to talk about John Weaver, a co-founder who harassed young men online. The leaders were also criticized by journalists and others after the group, without authorization, posted screenshots of another co-founder’s private Twitter messages with a reporter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: How a Queens Shaobing Stall Survives a Pandemic
description: Yukun Shaobing’s stuffed flatbreads have become a hit in Flushing despite the pressures of Covid and high rents.
content: As several restaurants in Flushing, Queens, one of the largest Chinatowns in New York City, shut down amid the pandemic, Yukun Shaobing quietly opened inside a nondescript mini-mall last September — a seemingly inauspicious start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Christopher F. Schuetze, Natasha Frost and Rebecca Halleck
title: As the Australian Open plays on, Victoria officials order a ‘circuit breaker’ Covid lockdown.
description: The tournament will continue, though without spectators, as professional athletes are deemed essential workers under new restrictions in Victoria state.
content: More than six million people in Victoria, Australia, will enter into a snap lockdown for five days in response to a coronavirus outbreak at a quarantine hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Valparaiso U. Drops Crusader as Mascot, Citing Ties to Hate Groups
description: The private university in Indiana, which is affiliated with the Lutheran Church, said the Crusader name could be associated with “aggressive religious oppression and violence.”
content: Valparaiso University, which is known for one of the biggest upsets in the history of the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball tournament by a mid-major athletic program, announced on Thursday that it was dropping the Crusader as its mascot because of its association with hate groups and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Using Instagram and Acrobatics, Thieves Targeted V.I.P.s in Milan
description: Four men have been arrested in connection with audacious heists that netted tens of thousands of euros in watches, scarves, designer bags and jewels.
content: Eleonora Incardona’s opulent posts of herself on the beach or dressed to the nines with chunky watches and golden necklaces were intended to catch the eye of her 470,000-plus followers on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Knows How the Impeachment Sequel Will End
description: “It’s kind of like ‘The Empire Strikes Back,’” Kimmel said. “We already know how it ends, but we’re watching it anyway.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Goodbye to Fans at the Australian Open
description: A new coronavirus lockdown for the state of Victoria means five days of no fans at the Grand Slam tournament.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The reigning men’s champion Novak Djokovic was on the ropes on Friday when Melburnians were made to leave Rod Laver Arena. It was 30 minutes before the clock struck midnight, a Cinderella-like moment when their freedom turned to confinement and their lives reverted to what they experienced during a 111-day lockdown last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: When Can I Be a House Guest Again?
description: Vaccines are rolling out, but we still have a long way to go. We asked experts to give us a clue about when we can just go to a friend’s house and hang out.
content: A few days ago, I stopped by my best friend’s house to meet up for a brisk winter walk, and I caught a glimpse of the new royal blue sofa in her living room. Admiring her purchase, I no longer wanted to walk in 20-degree weather. I wanted to curl up on that sofa for the rest of the afternoon and drink coffee with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Takeaways From Day 4 of Trump’s Impeachment Trial
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s team presented its defense to senators, using far less than the allotted 16 hours.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers opened and closed their impeachment defense in a span of three hours on Friday. They called the House’s charge against Mr. Trump a “preposterous and monstrous lie,” and their arguments drew praise from Republican senators. After the defense rested, senators submitted questions to each side. Closing arguments are set to begin on Saturday, most likely followed by a swift verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Sciolino
title: A New, Safe Home for the Louvre’s Unseen Treasures
description: An ultramodern conservation center in northern France is a haven for flood-threatened items from the museum’s central Paris basement.
content: LIÉVIN, France — It is the most ambitious move in the history of the Louvre — a five-year project to transfer a quarter of a million artworks to an ultramodern storage site 120 miles away in northern France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sherrilyn A. Ifill
title: Lawyers Enabled Trump’s Worst Abuses
description: The legal profession must reckon with its complicity in Trump’s attack on democracy.
content: Every day, we learn more about the concerted attack on American democracy perpetuated to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. But the violent storming of the Capitol was only its most visible and ugly climax. What has become disturbingly and abundantly clear is that whether through former President Donald Trump’s relentless and meritless lawsuits, the plot in the Department of Justice to remove the acting attorney general, or a congressional plan in which members — including two former Supreme Court clerks — perpetuated false unsubstantiated claims of massive voter fraud, lawyers played a central role in enabling the most dangerous assault on American democracy in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar May Target Free Speech in Effort to Stifle Protests
description: Civil society groups say a proposed measure to limit online expression and privacy rights could lead to mass arrests of those who criticize the military government.
content: The military government in Myanmar has increasingly used nighttime arrests, legal threats, a curfew and a ban on large gatherings to tame weeklong anti-coup protests that have spread from the cities to the countryside. Now, civil society groups fear that the military is preparing a new law that would further restrict online expression and limit the privacy rights of citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: French Mayor Opens Museums, Defying Coronavirus Orders
description: Cultural institutions in France have been clamoring to reopen for months. They found an unlikely champion in a far-right civic official in Perpignan.
content: If you wanted to visit a museum in France this week, you were out of luck. On Monday, all — from the Louvre in Paris, to hundreds of local museums — were shut, as they had been since Oct. 30, when the government ordered them closed in the face of rising coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Does Your Country’s National Anthem Mean to You?
description: Does the song reflect the beliefs you have about your country? How might it be changed to include more perspectives and experiences?
content: In the United States, the national anthem, “The Star-Spangled Banner” by Francis Scott Key, is often performed before sporting events, school functions and other important events. Think about the last time you attended or watched an event on TV where the anthem was played. How did you feel hearing the song? Were you moved by the performance and the lyrics? Did you stand or remove your hat? Or did you feel uncomfortable or unaffected by the song?
source.name: The New York Times

title: This Land Is Whose Land?
description: Simon Winchester talks about “Land: How the Hunger for Ownership Shaped the Modern World,” and Amelia Pang discusses “Made in China.”
content: When Simon Winchester takes on a big subject, he takes on a big subject. His new book, “Land: How the Hunger for Ownership Shaped the Modern World,” travels through centuries and to places like Ukraine, New Zealand, Scotland, the United States and elsewhere. On this week’s podcast, he talks about the history of private land ownership and a few of the many aspects of this history that caught his attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Coming Technology Boom
description: Politics is grim but science is working.
content: A few months ago, the economic analyst Noah Smith observed that scientific advance is like mining ore. You find a vein you think is promising. You take a risk and invest heavily. You explore it until it taps out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Shaka King Goes to Hollywood
description: How the “Judas and the Black Messiah” filmmaker went from outsider to trailblazer with a studio movie about the Black Panther leader Fred Hampton.
content: Shaka King was feeling depressed. It was his last scheduled day at the 2013 Sundance Film Festival, and the trip hadn’t gone well. King’s directorial debut, a bittersweet comedy about the misadventures of a marijuana-addicted couple called “Newlyweeds,” had been rejected by seemingly every major company in Hollywood. “Newlyweeds” had cost King and his investors six figures, but it eventually sold, to a small Canadian distributor, for just $25,000 — a result that still leaves a bad taste in his mouth. Even the weather seemed to be against King — a nasty snowstorm in Park City, Utah, had grounded his flight home to New York, leaving him stranded in town for a deflating extra night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Grape-Nuts Expected to Be Back on Store Shelves Next Month
description: After an outcry by customers on social media, Post Consumer Brands plans to have the cereal back on store shelves by mid-March.
content: After a monthslong, nationwide shortage of its polarizing cereal, the maker of Grape-Nuts is trying to reassure customers that the familiar wheat-and-barley breakfast will soon be back, still with no grapes or nuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Lemonides
title: Ohio begins adding 4,000 overlooked Covid deaths to its official count.
description: The deaths, some of which dated back to October, had not been properly merged between one reporting system and another, the state’s Department of Health said.
content: Ohio health officials said they had overlooked about 4,000 deaths that occurred over the past several months and would begin reporting them to the public this week. The announcement came just as deaths nationwide had started to ebb after peaking in mid-January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: The Question Some Company Owners Don’t Want to Deal With
description: Tales from two sons whose fathers died without a succession plan.
content: Ivo Puidak, who cooked for Presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan as the head chef at the Federal Reserve Bank in Chicago, built the Galena Canning Company into a thriving specialty food business, selling premium barbecue sauces, salsas and seasonings around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: Hey, Alexa, Are You Sexist?
description: “Add milk to the grocery list.” “Switch off the lights.” It’s no coincidence that our robotic helpers at home have feminine voices.
content: — Amazon’s Alexa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 Australian Open: What to Watch on Friday Night
description: Rafael Nadal and Ashleigh Barty are in the spotlight after easing through the first two rounds of the Australian Open.
content: How to watch: 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Eastern on the Tennis Channel and 9 p.m. to 7 a.m. on ESPN2 in the United States; streaming on the ESPN+ and ESPN3 apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Olbermann
title: Is This the End of Obsessively Hating Donald Trump?
description: Loathing him has been a passion, an addiction, a compulsion. Let impeachment be the last hurrah.
content: I hated Donald Trump when hating Donald Trump wasn’t cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Man Is Charged With Threatening to Kill Biden
description: David K. Reeves of North Carolina made the threats over a period of several days ending on Feb. 2, in calls to the White House, the U.S. Capitol Police and a Secret Service agent, prosecutors said.
content: A 27-year-old man who made several phone calls to the White House in which he threatened to kill President Biden and Secret Service agents has been arrested in North Carolina on federal charges, officials announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Rory Smith
title: Barcelona and the Crippling Cost of Success
description: The world’s richest soccer club is facing a financial crisis. Executives blame the pandemic, but many of its biggest problems, including its enormous debt to Lionel Messi, are its own fault.
content: The careful plan hatched by Barcelona, the richest soccer club in the world, fell apart almost as soon as its negotiators entered the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: S. Prestley Blake, a Founder of Friendly’s, Dies at 106
description: With a $547 loan from their parents, he and a brother opened the Friendly Ice Cream Shop in 1935, then built it into a chain of hundreds of restaurants.
content: S. Prestley Blake, who with his brother built a Massachusetts ice cream shop into the Friendly’s restaurant chain, sold it for a huge profit in the 1970s and decades later helped engineer a takeover threat to protest what he saw as mismanagement, died on Thursday in Stuart, Fla. He was 106.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle White
title: Please Go Shelter in Another Place
description: During lockdown, a 25-year marriage shakes and resettles.
content: On our 25th day of sheltering-in-place, my husband packed a suitcase and a brown paper bag of food and moved into an Airbnb some two miles away. Our quarter-century-long marriage was faltering, and we needed time apart, so off he went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: The Californians Are Coming. So Is Their Housing Crisis.
description: Is it possible to import growth without also importing housing problems? “I can’t point to a city that has done it right.”
content: Statistically speaking, Idaho is one of America’s greatest economic success stories. The state has low unemployment and high income growth. It has expanded education spending while managing to shore up budget reserves. Brad Little, the state’s Republican governor, has attributed this run of prosperity to the mix of low taxes and minimal regulation that conservatives call “the business climate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Emily Bazelon
title: A New Delay for Census Numbers Could Scramble Congressional Elections
description: Census data needed for legislative districts won’t be ready until September. Could that alter the balance of power in the House?
content: WASHINGTON — The delivery date for the 2020 census data used in redistricting, delayed first by the coronavirus pandemic and then by the Trump administration’s interference, now is so late that it threatens to scramble the 2022 elections, including races for Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Impeachment Offers Republicans Grace. They Don’t Want It.
description: House managers are treating Trump’s enablers as his victims.
content: During her impeachment presentation on Wednesday, Stacey Plaskett, who represents the Virgin Islands in the House, explained how Donald Trump winked at violence from his base in the weeks leading up to the Jan. 6 Capitol attack. She showed a video of Nick Fuentes, a white supremacist, bellowing through a bullhorn at the second so-called Million MAGA March in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: For Shell, Oil Is Past Its Peak
description: Now comes the hard part.
content: With an announcement yesterday — buried in fine print — that its total oil production had peaked in 2019, Royal Dutch Shell made a bold statement about the end of the oil age. Now comes the hard part for the energy giant, writes The Times’s Stanley Reed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Judas and the Black Messiah’: What to Know About the HBO Max Film
description: The Shaka King movie dramatizes the life and death of Fred Hampton, chairman of the Illinois Black Panther Party. Here’s a guide to the people and the issues of the day.
content: To Black Americans in the 1960s who were targeted and harassed by the police, 21-year-old Fred Hampton was an empowering figure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For Derek Jeter, a Hall of Fame Induction Without the Fans
description: Cooperstown’s annual outdoor celebration was canceled last year and will be held at a private indoor ceremony this year because of logistical concerns related to the pandemic.
content: The Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremony is that rarest of major events: free to spectators, with no strict capacity. The price you pay is in the effort to get to Cooperstown, N.Y., a quaint upstate village by Otsego Lake. The reward is a spot on a field beside the Clark Sports Center, with the greatest players in history gathered on a stage.

content: There are things you learn, reporting on institutions like the Senate, that never quite make it into your stories. They’re a mood, not a news break. But they matter. And here’s one: Almost everybody in the Senate hates what the body has become. This is not a case where it takes an outsider’s perspective to see an institution’s flaws. You will never hear more searing denunciations than you do from the insiders themselves. They may disagree on what’s wrong, and how to fix it.
